document_title: Congenital heart disease: Signs of recognition, screening and treatment
subsection_content:
Symptoms of congenital heart disease in children may not show obvious symptoms or "come late" causing delay in detecting the disease, which can lead to death or many other dangerous complications. Statistics show that about 10-15% of sick newborns need medical treatment or surgery in the first month of life. Therefore, screening by measuring oxygen saturation is now performed on all newborns before discharge from the hospital.
Next, cases with suspicious signs are comprehensively diagnosed to accurately detect the cause by means of:
Electrocardiogram ECG;; Chest X-ray;; Echocardiography;; Routine blood tests (when necessary); Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging or cardiac computed tomography or cardiac catheterization, in some cases.
See more: Can fetal echocardiography detect congenital heart disease?
Depending on the examination and necessary tests, each patient will have a specific treatment regimen
